abstract.text: A node that plays audio.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: A
object is used to add an audio to a scene. The sounds are played automatically using AVFoundation, and the node can optionally add 3D spatial audio effects to the audio when it is played.
The currently presented
object mixes the audio from nodes in the scene based on parameters defined in the
protocol. A scene’s
property allows overall control of volume and playback.
By default,
objects are positional, i.e. their
property is set to
. If you add an audio node to a scene with a
set, SpriteKit will set the stereo balance and the volume based on the relative positions of the two nodes.
You can explicitly set the volume or stereo balance to an audio node by running actions on it.

SpriteKit includes actions that reduce an audio node’s volume by changing either its occlusion or obstruction. The difference between these actions is that occlusion affects both the direct and reverb paths of the sound while obstruction only affects the direct path. The
change volume
action offers absolute control over an audio node’s volume.
You can manually set the stereo balance of an audio node with a
stereo pan
action.
Special effects, such as speeding up or slowing down audio by changing the playback rate and adding reverb are also available as audio actions.
To learn more about audio actions, see Controlling the Audio of a Node in

abstract.text: A collection of properties that define 3D mixing properties.
A true value.
Add high-performance 2D content with smooth animations to your app, or create a game with a high-level set of 2D game-based tools.
A node that plays audio.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the audio should play in a loop when the node is added to the scene.
The audio node’s current audio asset.
Initializes an audio node from an AVFoundation audio node.
Tells you when to initialize an audio node that has been unarchived.
Initializes an audio node from an audio asset with the specified filename.
Initializes an audio node from an audio asset with the specified URL.
A Boolean property that indicates whether the node’s audio is altered based on the position of the node.
A node that applies physics effects to nearby nodes.
A node that lights surrounding nodes.
The base class of all SpriteKit nodes.
An object that organizes all of the active SpriteKit content.
The AVFoundation audio engine used to play audio from audio nodes contained in the scene.
A node used to determine the position of the listener for positional audio in the scene.
Use these functions to create actions.
Add audio to your scene, and optionally give it 2D-positional mixing characteristics.

doc://com.apple.spritekit/documentation/.title: Using Audio Nodes with the Scene’s Listener

abstract.text: A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
A protocol that objects adopt to provide functional copies of themselves.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A protocol that enables encoding and decoding in a manner that is robust against object substitution attacks.
Methods that responder subclasses implement to support key binding commands, such as inserting tabs and newlines, or moving the insertion point.
A protocol that an object adopts to create a bar object in your app.
A protocol that marks classes to restore the state of your app to continue a user activity.
An interface that provides a source for shareable content to fulfill user requests to share current content.
A set of methods for converting between different frames of reference on a screen.
A set of methods that define the focus behavior for a branch of the view hierarchy.
An object that can become focused.
The container responsible for providing geometric context to focus items within a given focus environment.
The interface that determines whether a responder object supports paste configuration.
A set of standard methods that apps can adopt to support editing.
The protocol you adopt to restore an object’s state from a user activity.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
